summary: The Madina Shopping Mall Association (appellants) appealed a lower court decision dismissing their claim for ownership of shops they had paid for at the Rosehill Height Shopping Mall. They argued that the payments made to Rosehill Gh. Ltd. and its Managing Director, E. M. Frimpong, were for the outright purchase of shops, supported by an oral agreement. However, the Supreme Court upheld the Court of Appeal's finding that no enforceable contract existed because essential terms, particularly price, were not agreed upon. The application form (Exhibit E) did not mention sale, only allocation after deposit, and required a next-of-kinâ€”insufficient to prove ownership. The court rejected the fraud claim, noting the appellants signed the forms without protest. While affirming dismissal, the court ordered restitution of monies paid with simple interest from the date of occupation termination to final payment, less any rent paid by those who accepted tenancy, citing its inherent jurisdiction to prevent miscarriage of justice.
verdict: Appeal dismissed with variation for restitution of monies paid with interest, less rent paid by those who accepted tenancy.
citations: MAY AND BUTCHER vrs. R, HOUSE OF LORDS [1934]2 KB 17
BRITISH BANK FOR FOREIGN TRADE vrs. NOVINEX LTD. [1949] 1 KB.623, 1 ALL ER. 155
NTHC LTD v ANTWI (2009) SC GLR 117
HANNA ASSI (No. 2) v. GHIHOC REFRIGERATION & HOUSEHOLD PRODUCTS LTD (No. 2) [2007-2008] SC GLR 16
rationaleHighlights: No enforceable contract due to absence of agreed essential terms like price
Exhibit E did not mention sale, undermining claim of outright purchase
Next-of-kin provision does not prove ownership transfer
Goodwill payments for commercial premises are legally permissible
Court exercised inherent jurisdiction to order restitution with interest
Fraud claim dismissed due to appellants signing forms without objection
Reference to binding precedent on incomplete contracts
Emphasis on written terms over oral assertions
